dukeD

I've always suspected them to be just treacherous beasts. How do you like that much boasted "peaceful project USA-France"? I got a big chuckle out of it. 200 military constructors (!) is French contribution into cause of peace in the Middle East. They are kidding us! And they are just exploiting us! American participation in the project is meant by France only to make it look weighty. 
 Methinks France's hidden agenda here is restoring its lost positions in Lebanon. And her secret talks with the Cyprus over French military base there also fit the plan well. I feel wily French are set to keep an eye over all Eastern Mediterranean out from there and not only Lebanon. Does it suit "Broader Middle East" doctrine worked out by our joint effort with Britain? In no way I guess. It's a challenge to it actually. 
 
 But they've already dragged us into that trap! And UN resolutions are going to be their most efficient tool to keep us there. In more distant future France's cherished idea is the Middle East as EU domain with France on the throne.
 How could this big gaffe of our State Dep. happen? It was just seduced by France. Frankly, I've got no clue. Could they be lobby or something like that?

post_info.post_title: France is not the sort of ally to rely on

Jo Bennett

*ahem*
 
 http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/5287084.stm
 
 Checking the new might be a good idea before going off on a rant. If it's too difficult for you to fathom, I'll point out the key issue:
 
UN TROOP PLEDGES 
 France - leadership and 2,000 troops
Steeeeve

Makes you wonder though...if they cave that fast to pressure than how can they handle the situation down there?
 
 France has always been odd when it comes to the military hehe.
Judeau

I agree Steeeeve, when you read the bottom of the article it says that France pulled 90% of their stated support. (2000 to 200.) I don't know about them trying to rebuild some former French colonial empire but I am pretty sure that if France did want to rebuild its lost colonies, it would have to use weasling and negotiating because their military is laughable at best. Honestly, their military is very small and their shrinking economy. I don't know how they can consider themselves one of the top 5 (security council members) powers in the world.
Collin

I agree Steeeeve, when you read the bottom of the article it says that France pulled 90% of their stated support. (2000 to 200.) I don't know about them trying to rebuild some former French colonial empire but I am pretty sure that if France did want to rebuild its lost colonies, it would have to use weasling and negotiating because their military is laughable at best. Honestly, their military is very small and their shrinking economy. I don't know how they can consider themselves one of the top 5 (security council members) powers in the world.

 
 Nevermind a small military so long as it is professional and an effective peacekeeping force. France participates with NATO routinely.
Ripskar

Honestly, their military is very small and their shrinking economy. I don't know how they can consider themselves one of the top 5 (security council members) powers in the world.

 
 Two words; Nuclear Weaponry. The original setup for the Security Council was to include all the nuclear armed countries as permanent members under the rationalisation that if they didn't it would be a joke. Of course now Isreal, Pakistan and India are nuclear amed that doesn't seem to be such a defining factor. 
 Shrinking Economy; That would be the Euro, basicly the one size fits all view is completely wrong and left the whole Eurozone barely avoiding recession.
Jo Bennett

It's not nuclear weapons that are key, most of the countries didn't have nukes at the time the UN was set up. It's simply that those 5 countries were the victors in WW2. France didn't commit troops early on because the mandate of the force was completely unknown, and unlike the US and UK, the French are sane enough to realise that sending your troops into a warzone with unclear mandate and rules of engagement is a bad idea.
Collin

Shrinking Economy; That would be the Euro, basicly the one size fits all view is completely wrong and left the whole Eurozone barely avoiding recession.

 
 What are you talking about? Compared to the USD, the euro is a resounding success. It took a few years for the EU to come online, but it certainly has by now.
Ripskar

And compared to non-Euro european economies it's been an unmitigated disaster, to the point where France Germany and Italy all broke the stability pact and Italy is openly talking about dropping the Euro alltogether.
georged

And compared to non-Euro european economies it's been an unmitigated disaster, to the point where France Germany and Italy all broke the stability pact and Italy is openly talking about dropping the Euro alltogether.

 
 I just looked at Italy's economic picture, not a pretty sight. Debt 108% of GDP (mostly external), 63% of work force in services, negative payment balance, no economic growth and high unemployment. I'm sure they're lusting to crank up their own printing presses.
Collin

And compared to non-Euro european economies it's been an unmitigated disaster, to the point where France Germany and Italy all broke the stability pact and Italy is openly talking about dropping the Euro alltogether.

 
 Good point. It'd be a lot nicer of a world for them if they didn't have to pick up the pieces for the not-so-wealthy. Probably an accurate picture of what it would look like if the U.S. and Mexico created a mutual currency.
ibelieveyou

is French contribution into cause of peace in the Middle East. They are kidding us! And they are just exploiting us! 

 
 the above stood out, claiming foreigners (with 1 obvious exception) exploiting the US is akin to claiming iraqi prisoners were brutalizing marines in abu grahid by bleeding over their torturers
